Purpose.Description: Defines how an organization identifies, prioritizes, and reports material topics. Material topics are issues with the most significant environmental, social, and economic impacts.
Outcome: A clear list of material topics
Links to relevant GRI Topic Standards

Core_Concepts.Material_Impacts: Actual or potential, positive or negative, short-term or long-term effects the organization has on people and the environment.
Core_Concepts.Stakeholder_Perspectives: Understanding concerns, expectations, and legitimate interests of affected groups.
Core_Concepts.Impact_Significance: Magnitude, scale, scope, likelihood, and remediability of impacts.
Core_Concepts.Value_Chain_Coverage: Material topics include impacts across upstream, direct operations, and downstream activities.
Core_Concepts.Relationship_to_Financial_Materiality: Although GRI focuses on impacts, some material topics may also be financially relevant.

3.1_Process_for_Identifying_Material_Top.Guidance: Map all major activities, products, services, and the full value chain including suppliers, operations, logistics, and consumers.
Document all known and possible environmental and social impacts caused by or linked to the organization.
Gather perspectives from workers, communities, investors, customers, regulators, and affected groups.
Evaluate magnitude, scale, likelihood, severity, duration, and context of impacts.
Select topics representing the most significant impacts requiring management and disclosure.

Environmental: Land use and natural resource extraction

3.3_Assessing_Impact_Significance.Guidance: Severity of the impact on people or the environment (minor to catastrophic).
How widespread the impact is — local, regional, national, global.
Extent to which the impact can be reversed or compensated.
Probability of the impact occurring (for potential impacts).
Whether the harms disproportionately impact children, women, Indigenous groups, low-income workers, etc.
Whether the impact influences long-term strategy, reputation, license to operate, or stakeholder trust.

3.4_Stakeholder_Engagement_in_Materialit.Guidance: Workers, local communities, Indigenous peoples, customers, NGOs, regulators, investors, suppliers.
Interviews, surveys, consultations, grievance data, board dialogues, union feedback, community meetings.
Stakeholder issues must influence materiality decisions, but do not solely define them.

3.5_Determining_Material_Topics.Guidance: Material topics must reflect the organization’s most important environmental and social impacts.
Consider expectations of people affected, investors, customers, communities, and workers.
Consider local regulations, national priorities, global sustainability challenges (SDGs, climate, equity).
Material topics must include impacts beyond the company’s direct operations when relevant.

Contractors
Raw material extraction
Agricultural inputs
Factories
Warehouses
Offices
Service centers
Product use phase
Customers
Distributors
End-of-life management

Standard_Overview.Objective: To disclose how the organization uses materials, prioritizes recycled or renewable content, and advances circular economy practices.

Key_Concepts.Primary_Materials: Raw materials extracted from natural resources (e.g., metals, minerals, petrochemicals, timber).
Key_Concepts.Secondary_Materials: Recycled or recovered materials used as input instead of virgin materials.
Key_Concepts.Renewable_Materials: Materials sourced from naturally replenishing resources (e.g., bamboo, bio-based plastics).
Key_Concepts.Circular_Design: Product design enabling reuse, repair, refurbishing, remanufacturing, or recycling.
Key_Concepts.Resource_Efficiency: Reducing material intensity per unit of production or revenue.

Required_Elements.Guidance: Disclose responsible sourcing policies, circularity commitments, and goals for recycled or renewable content.

Describe actions to reduce material waste, increase recycled content, improve product design, and enable reuse or recycling.

Report targets for reducing virgin material use, increasing recycled content, or improving circularity.

Standard_Overview.Objective: To disclose how the organization consumes energy, sources renewable energy, improves efficiency, and contributes to climate and resource objectives.

Key_Concepts.Non_Renewable_Energy: Energy sourced from fossil fuels such as coal, natural gas, diesel, petrol, and furnace oil.
Key_Concepts.Renewable_Energy: Energy from solar, wind, geothermal, hydro, biomass, or certified renewable power purchase agreements.
Key_Concepts.Direct_Energy: Fuel directly consumed on-site (for boilers, vehicles, furnaces, generators).
Key_Concepts.Indirect_Energy: Purchased electricity, heating, cooling, or steam.
Key_Concepts.Energy_Intensity: Energy used per unit output (per tonne, per product, per square meter, or per revenue).
Key_Concepts.Energy_Transition: Movement from fossil-based energy to renewable and efficient energy systems.

Required_Elements.Guidance: Describe policies promoting energy efficiency, renewable adoption, and reduction of fossil fuel dependency.
Identify roles responsible for energy planning, audits, efficiency programs, and renewable integration.
Explain risks related to energy price volatility, grid reliability, and regulatory changes.
Programs targeting equipment upgrades, process optimization, building improvements, or digital monitoring.
Describe adoption plans such as rooftop solar, PPAs, renewable certificates, and energy storage.
Report targets for reducing energy consumption intensity and increasing renewable share.

Standard_Overview.Objective: To disclose how the organization withdraws, consumes, reuses, and discharges water, including water-related risks and impacts across the value chain.

Key_Concepts.Water_Withdrawal: Total water removed from surface, ground, sea, or third-party sources.
Key_Concepts.Water_Consumption: Water that is evaporated, transpired, incorporated into products, or not returned to the source.
Key_Concepts.Water_Discharge: Water returned to surface water, groundwater, or third-party systems after treatment.
Key_Concepts.Water_Stress: Areas where freshwater availability is limited or declining due to physical or regulatory pressures.
Key_Concepts.Catchment: Geographical drainage area from which a site withdraws or to which it discharges water.
Key_Concepts.Effluents: Wastewater containing physical, chemical, or biological pollutants discharged to the environment or utility systems.

Standard_Overview.Objective: To disclose how the organization affects biodiversity across its operations and value chain, and how it manages, mitigates, or restores impacts.

Key_Concepts.Biodiversity: Variety of living organisms and ecosystems, including genetic, species, and habitat diversity.
Key_Concepts.High_Value_Biodiversity_Area: Region that hosts endangered species, critical ecosystems, or high conservation value habitats.
Key_Concepts.Protected_Area: Area legally designated for conservation (national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, Ramsar sites, UNESCO reserves).
Key_Concepts.Critical_Habitat: Areas essential for survival of endangered or migratory species.
Key_Concepts.Ecosystem_Services: Benefits humans derive from ecosystems (water filtration, carbon storage, pollination).
Key_Concepts.Restoration: Activities that rehabilitate ecosystems to a stable or improved condition.

Required_Elements.Guidance: Describe commitments to avoid habitat loss, reduce land-use impacts, and protect endangered species.
Explain biodiversity and ecological risk assessments performed before, during, and after operations.
Describe measures to prevent habitat conversion, fragmentation, and ecosystem damage.
Explain habitat restoration, conservation offsets, or reforestation projects.
Engage with local communities, Indigenous groups, regulators, and conservation organizations.
Describe ongoing biodiversity monitoring and ecosystem health indicators.

304-1_Operational_Sites_in_Protected_or_.Purpose: Identify which operations are located within or near protected or sensitive ecological regions.
Data_Requirements: List of sites within protected areas
Sites within 5–10 km of high-value biodiversity zones
Guidance: Use recognized classifications (IUCN categories, Ramsar, UNESCO).
Provide geospatial coordinates for significant sites.
Explain potential ecological sensitivities.
Examples: Mining pits near forest reserves
Plantations near tiger corridors
Industrial units near wetlands

304-2_Significant_Impacts_on_Biodiversit.Purpose: Describe the organization’s actual or potential impacts on ecosystems.
Impact_Types: Noise and light pollution affecting species
Disturbance to breeding or nesting grounds
Guidance: Include value-chain impacts: sourcing, logistics, and product use.
Describe cumulative impacts in shared ecosystems.
Assess impacts on ecosystem services (e.g., water filtration, carbon storage).

304-3_Habitats_Protected_or_Restored.Purpose: Show the organization’s contribution to preserving or restoring ecological areas.
Data_Requirements: Collaborations with NGOs, governments, Indigenous groups
Guidance: Describe the ecological objectives of restoration.
Provide before/after ecological condition assessments.
Explain species or habitat-specific actions.
Examples: Reforestation of degraded land
River clean-up and wetland restoration
Coral reef rehabilitation
Protection of grasslands or mangroves

304-4_IUCN_Red_List_Species_and_National.Purpose: Identify species impacted by operations that are classified as threatened.
Data_Requirements: IUCN Red List status (CR, EN, VU)
Nature of the impact (habitat loss, pollution, disturbance)
Guidance: Review scientific sources and ecological studies.
Consider migratory, endemic, and keystone species.
Explain site-level monitoring results.
Examples: Endangered big cats in mining corridors
Vulnerable aquatic species near effluent discharge points
Threatened bird species near wind farms

Standard_Overview.Objective: To disclose greenhouse gas emissions and air pollutants, explain calculation methodologies, and highlight efforts to reduce emissions and transition to low-carbon operations.

GHG_Scopes.Scope_1: Direct emissions from owned or controlled sources (fuel use, boilers, furnaces, vehicles, generators).
GHG_Scopes.Scope_2: Indirect emissions from purchased electricity, heat, cooling, or steam.
GHG_Scopes.Scope_3: Other indirect emissions occurring in the value chain (categories as per GHG Protocol).

Key_Concepts.Emission_Factors: Conversion factors used to compute emissions from energy use, fuels, or processes.
Key_Concepts.Market_Based_Scope_2: Emissions calculated based on contractual instruments (e.g., renewable PPAs).
Key_Concepts.Air_Pollutants: NOx, SOx, PM, VOC, CO, heavy metals, and hazardous air pollutants.
Key_Concepts.Global_Warming_Potential: Multipliers (e.g., CO₂e) used to convert gases like CH₄ or N₂O into CO₂ equivalents.

Elements.Guidance: Describe commitments to reduce carbon emissions, comply with air quality regulations, and avoid ozone-depleting compounds.
Explain boundaries, consolidation approach (operational/financial control), emission factors, and data quality controls.
Identify board and management responsibilities for climate, emissions, and low-carbon strategies.
Outline initiatives such as renewable energy procurement, fuel switching, energy efficiency, green hydrogen, EV fleets.
State reduction targets (absolute, intensity), net-zero goals, SBTi alignment, and progress.
Describe internal verification, external assurance, data validation, and MRV systems.

305-1_Scope_1_Direct_GHG_Emissions.Purpose: Disclose direct GHG emissions from owned or controlled sources.
Guidance: Use recognized emission factors (IPCC, national databases).
Disclose gases included (CO₂, CH₄, N₂O, SF₆, HFCs, PFCs).
Explain methodology for fugitive emissions.
Examples: Diesel combustion emissions
Natural gas boiler emissions
Refrigerant leaks from cooling systems

305-2_Scope_2_Indirect_GHG_Emissions.Purpose: Report emissions from purchased electricity, heating, cooling, and steam.
Guidance: Market-based method must consider renewable certificates or PPAs.
Use country or region-specific grid emission factors.
Explain origin of emission factors (e.g., IEA data).
Examples: Electricity from national grid
Steam purchased from industrial utility providers

Guidance: Explain boundaries and materiality of categories.
Use supplier-specific data where possible.
Describe estimation methodologies when primary data unavailable.
Examples: Emissions from purchased raw materials
Customer use-phase emissions of appliances
Logistics-related emissions from third parties

305-4_GHG_Emissions_Intensity.Purpose: Show emissions normalized to activity or output.
Intensity_Options: tCO₂e per crore or million revenue
Guidance: Disclose intensity separately for Scope 1, 2, and 3.
Explain significant changes in intensity trends.

305-5_Reduction_of_GHG_Emissions.Purpose: Report reductions achieved through efficiency, renewable energy, process improvements, or behavior changes.
Guidance: Describe calculation methods for avoided emissions.
Separate structural vs actual reductions.

305-6_Ozone-Depleting_Substances_(ODS).Purpose: Report emissions of ozone-depleting refrigerants or chemicals.
Guidance: Explain compliance with Montreal Protocol.
Disclose replacement with non-ODS alternatives.
Examples: R22 phase-out plans
ODS refrigerant replacement with R410A or R32

305-7_Nitrogen_Oxides_(NOx), Sulfur_Oxid.Purpose: Report air pollutants harmful to human health and ecosystems.
Guidance: Report regulatory exceedances or penalties.

NOx from diesel gensets
Dust emissions from mining operations

Risks: Market access risk due to high emissions

Standard_Overview.Objective: To disclose how an organization generates, manages, treats, transports, and disposes of waste, and how it promotes circularity and waste reduction.

Key_Concepts.Operational_Waste: Waste generated from core operations such as manufacturing, maintenance, packaging, and service activities.
Key_Concepts.Non_Operational_Waste: Waste generated from offices, administration, retail stores, and non-manufacturing functions.
Key_Concepts.Hazardous_Waste: Waste that poses risks to health or the environment (toxic, flammable, corrosive, reactive).
Key_Concepts.Non_Hazardous_Waste: Waste that does not contain hazardous properties (paper, food waste, scrap, plastics).
Key_Concepts.Circular_Economy: A system that reduces material waste through design, reuse, recycling, and resource recovery.

Elements.Guidance: Describe policies for waste minimization, segregation, treatment, and circular economy.
Assign roles for waste handling, hazardous waste oversight, regulatory compliance, and vendor selection.
Explain how waste-related risks (pollution, spills, contamination, regulatory breach) are assessed and mitigated.
Describe segregation at source, containment, labeling, storage, and safe handling procedures.
Explain waste treatment hierarchy and criteria for choosing disposal methods.
Highlight redesign, reuse, recycled materials, resource recovery, and waste-to-value programs.
Report reduction targets, recycling rates, % hazardous waste safely treated, and waste diversion rates.
Describe selection, audits, and monitoring of waste contractors to ensure legal and environmental compliance.

Effectiveness_Evaluation: Compliance with waste transport and disposal laws

Examples: Sludge from ETP plants
Expired chemicals
Food waste from canteens
Packaging waste from warehouses

ZLD compliance management

Guidance: Use weight-based units (tonnes preferred).
Explain methodology and consistency across years.
Highlight major increases or decreases.

Packaging waste
Spent solvents
Biomedical waste in healthcare

Guidance: Show alignment with circular economy goals.
Explain techniques enabling diversion.

Metal scrap sold for reuse
Organic waste composted

Standard_Overview.Objective: To disclose information on the organization’s workforce, hiring practices, turnover, benefits, and employee wellbeing.

Key_Concepts.Employee: A person working directly for the organization under a contract of employment.
Key_Concepts.Worker: Includes both employees and individuals working through contractors or agencies.
Key_Concepts.Turnover: Total number of employees leaving the organization voluntarily or involuntarily.
Key_Concepts.Benefits: Non-wage compensation such as insurance, parental leave, PF, health benefits.
Key_Concepts.Parental_Leave: Leave provided to employees for childbirth, adoption, or childcare responsibilities.

Required_Elements.Guidance: List policies covering hiring, equal opportunity, non-discrimination, and fair labor practices.
Describe how the organization anticipates workforce needs, skill gaps, and succession planning.
Explain structure of wages and statutory/non-statutory benefits.
Describe onboarding, employer branding, and recruiting practices.
Include surveys, communication channels, well-being programs, and feedback systems.
Explain how compliance with working hours, leave, PF, ESI, minimum wage, and contract labor regulations is ensured.

401-1_New_Employee_Hires_and_Employee_Tu.Purpose: Provide statistics on hiring and turnover to assess workforce stability and diversity.

Metadata.Purpose: Explains how the GRI Standards work, the core reporting principles, and expectations for using GRI in sustainability reporting.

GRI_Standards_Family.Description: The GRI Standards are a modular system with universal standards and topic-specific standards that can be combined depending on what is material for the organization.

Components.Role: Provide basic structure, general information requirements, and a method for identifying what topics are material.
Define disclosures for specific topics like emissions, water, human rights, labor, community, customers, etc.

Reporting_Options.Description: Organization uses selected GRI disclosures but does not prepare a report fully in accordance with GRI.
Organization follows the full set of GRI requirements (GRI 1, GRI 2, GRI 3, and applicable topic standards) and can say the report is prepared in accordance with GRI.

Minimum_Elements_for_In_Accordance: Clear description of reporting entities and boundaries
Disclosures for each material topic using relevant topic standards
Statement on the use of GRI Standards

Reporting_Principles.Overview: Reporting principles help determine what to report and how to ensure that reported information is decision-useful, fair, and understandable.

For_Content.Intent: Ensure the report covers topics that genuinely matter for the organization and its stakeholders.
Practical_Checks: Has the organization identified its most significant impacts?
Are key stakeholders and their concerns considered?
Are trivial topics avoided unless they are truly critical?

For_Content.Intent: Take stakeholder needs and expectations into account when deciding what information to include.
Practical_Checks: Have stakeholders been identified and segmented?
Have their main concerns and expectations been mapped?
Is the report addressing questions stakeholders typically ask?

For_Content.Intent: Place the organization’s performance in the wider environmental and social context instead of only showing internal trends.
Practical_Checks: Are performance metrics compared to global, national, or local sustainability challenges (e.g., climate, inequality)?
Does the report explain how the organization contributes positively or negatively to these broader issues?

For_Content.Intent: Ensure the report covers all relevant aspects of material topics, both in scope and time.
Practical_Checks: Is the full value chain considered where relevant?
Are both positive and negative impacts covered?
Does the time period allow a fair assessment (e.g., trends over several years)?

For_Quality.Intent: Data should be correct, sufficiently precise, and reliable.
Practical_Checks: Are calculation methods described?
Are units, conversion factors, and assumptions stated?
Is there internal review or assurance of key figures?

For_Quality.Intent: Present both strengths and weaknesses without cherry-picking only good news.
Practical_Checks: Are negative incidents or failures acknowledged?
Are explanations of underperformance honest and specific?
Is there a mix of positive and negative year-on-year trends?

For_Quality.Intent: Information should be easy to understand for non-experts.
Practical_Checks: Is jargon avoided or clearly explained?
Are tables/charts labelled and readable?
Is there a logical narrative linking topics together?

For_Quality.Intent: Allow users to compare performance over time and with other organizations where possible.
Practical_Checks: Are consistent metrics used across years?
Are changes in methodology clearly explained?
Are normalizing factors (e.g., per unit of output) provided?

For_Quality.Intent: Provide information frequently enough for users to make decisions.
Practical_Checks: Is the reporting frequency stated (annual, biennial, etc.)?
Are long time gaps avoided?
Is it clear up to which date the data is valid?

For_Quality.Intent: Reports should be easy to access, navigate, and reference.
Practical_Checks: Is there a clear index and navigation structure?
Is GRI content identifiable (e.g., GRI content index)?
Is the report available in accessible formats (e.g., PDF, web)?

Steps_for_In_Accordance.Description: Decide whether the organization aims to state that it is reporting 'in accordance with' GRI or is only referencing individual GRI disclosures.

Steps_for_In_Accordance.Name: Define_Reporting_Entities_and_Boundaries
Steps_for_In_Accordance.Description: Determine which entities, operations, and parts of the value chain are included in the report.

Steps_for_In_Accordance.Name: Apply_GRI_2_General_Disclosures
Steps_for_In_Accordance.Description: Collect and report general information about the organization, governance, strategy, policies, and practices.

Steps_for_In_Accordance.Name: Use_GRI_3_to_Identify_Material_Topics
Steps_for_In_Accordance.Description: Perform a structured materiality assessment using GRI 3 requirements and identify the organization’s material topics.

Steps_for_In_Accordance.Name: Select_Relevant_Topic_Standards
Steps_for_In_Accordance.Description: Match each material topic with appropriate GRI topic standards and determine which disclosures apply.

Steps_for_In_Accordance.Name: Prepare_Disclosures_for_Material_Topics
Steps_for_In_Accordance.Description: For each material topic, report management approach (how the topic is managed) and topic-specific metrics from the relevant GRI standard.

Steps_for_In_Accordance.Name: Compile_GRI_Content_Index
Steps_for_In_Accordance.Description: Create a GRI content index that lists all GRI 2, GRI 3, and topic standard disclosures used, with page or link references.

Steps_for_In_Accordance.Name: State_Use_of_GRI_Standards
Steps_for_In_Accordance.Description: Include a statement in the report clarifying whether it is prepared 'in accordance with' GRI or 'with reference to' GRI, and specify which standards were used.

Management_Approach.Description: For each material topic, GRI requires explaining how the organization manages the topic: governance, policies, responsibilities, due diligence, and performance evaluation.
Key_Elements: How impacts are identified and managed
How effectiveness of actions is evaluated
Any remediation or grievance channels related to the topic

Topic_Specific_Metrics.Description: Each topic standard defines quantitative and/or qualitative disclosures that give evidence of performance on the material topic.
Examples_of_Metric_Types: Quantities (e.g., emissions, water use, injuries, training hours)
Qualitative descriptions of policies, practices, and programs
Breakdowns by geography, gender, business unit, etc.

Data_Quality_Controls.Guidance: Each indicator should have a clear data owner responsible for collection, validation, and explanation.
Formulas, emission factors, conversion methods, and boundaries must be documented.
Draft data and narratives should go through internal review, including finance, sustainability, and relevant operational teams.

External_Assurance.Description: Organizations may choose to have some or all of their GRI disclosures externally assured to increase reliability.
Key_Questions: Which parts of the report are subject to assurance?
Which assurance standard or protocol is used?
What level of assurance (limited vs reasonable) is applied?

Elements_for_a_Proper_Statement: Whether the report is 'in accordance with' GRI or 'with reference to' GRI
Which GRI Standards (by name and year) have been used
Any significant deviations or limitations in application
Clarification of which entities and operations the GRI disclosures cover
Example_Use_Cases: ESG data books on corporate websites
